content.description: Start sitting on low edges and first move to a shelf. Climb up into a rail and huck for a crimp rail. Top out straight above.

climbs.name: Megatron
climbs.fa: Sam Edson? (or someone a long time ago)

content.description: Start with a left hand in a pocket sidepull and right hand on a one of two sidepull crimps. Pick your feet and dyno to the lip.Â
content.location: Far right of the project boulder where its short. To the left of the dirty mossy area

content.description: Start on the left side of the overhang and work up the arete until 10 feet from the top. Finally escape left onto the face. Scary!
content.location: Start on edges on the left arete.

content.description: As more has come to light about the history of this climb some added context is needed.While it may in fact be a 5.13 climb, it seems it has only been climbed free as a highball boulder problem. Dubbed "Fear Pressure" by Kevin Ryan, the initial crack is used until faceholds appear on the right. If climbed as a boulder, bring a lot of pads, a small above ground pool, or a large trampoline to land on.(Thanks to Andy Salo and others for uncovering this info!)
content.protection: Gear to .5 or a small above ground swimming pool.

content.description:
Start on a slopeing sidepull next to One Drop. Go out right to a crimp then up left to a nice quartz hold and top out straight up.

 Originally around V7, it's broken recently and yet to see a repeat. Perhaps 9-10 range now?
content.location: Directly to the right of one drop

content.description: This is it folks. The biggest, baddest pebble Vermont has. Maybe one of the best in New England.
